user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_SHA256_init:
```c
void
MHD_SHA256_init (struct Sha256Ctx *ctx)
{
  /* Initial hash values, see FIPS PUB 180-4 paragraph 5.3.3 */
  /* First thirty-two bits of the fractional parts of the square
   * roots of the first eight prime numbers: 2, 3, 5, 7, 11, 13,
   * 17, 19." */
  ctx->H[0] = UINT32_C (0x6a09e667);
  ctx->H[1] = UINT32_C (0xbb67ae85);
  ctx->H[2] = UINT32_C (0x3c6ef372);
  ctx->H[3] = UINT32_C (0xa54ff53a);
  ctx->H[4] = UINT32_C (0x510e527f);
  ctx->H[5] = UINT32_C (0x9b05688c);
  ctx->H[6] = UINT32_C (0x1f83d9ab);
  ctx->H[7] = UINT32_C (0x5be0cd19);

  /* Initialise number of bytes. */
  ctx->count = 0;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No unreachable code is present in the provided function. The body contains only a sequence of assignments to members of the supplied ctx object (ctx->H[0]..ctx->H[7] and ctx->count = 0) and comments. There are no control-flow constructs (no conditional statements, no loops, no goto/labels, no early return, no switch cases, no break/continue), and no conditional compilation blocks shown that could render any statements unreachable. The macro UINT32_C expands to constant integer literal wrappers and does not introduce branching or unreachable paths. Dereferencing ctx (e.g. if ctx is NULL) would be undefined behavior but is not 'unreachable code' as defined by MISRA C Rule 2.1, so it is not relevant to this rule. Therefore there are no fragments requiring investigation for unreachable code.
